data.title: Get Atom building on Constructicon
data.body:
This PR makes Atom buildable by Constructicon.

Depends on github/constructicon#7.

data.title: Non-github specific fallback for atom binary
data.body:
Theres only 2 hard coded binary paths related to boxen.

Fixes #334.

/cc @probablycorey

data.title: Elastic scrolling not working on editors
data.body: Can the rubber band scroll effect at the top and bottom of the editor when reaching the end of the scrollable area be enabled?  I'm not sure if this works yet on scrollable divs, but it would be nice.

data.title: Global search crashes UI
data.body: When searching for something in large repos (github and atom repos seem to work fine) it always crashes the UI.  Nothing works after this until I restart it.

data.title: Speed up clean builds by compiling .coffee/.cson files in parallel
data.body:
Instead of finding and compiling all `.coffee`/`.cson` files in `script/copy-files-to-bundle`, we now tell gyp how to do this for us. It works like this:
1. `Rakefile` invokes the new `script/generate-sources-gypi` script to generate `sources.gypi`. This file lists all the `.coffee`/`.cson` files in the `src`, `static`, and `vendor` directories, as well as a new `compiled_sources_dir` variable that specifies where the compiled versions of the files should be placed.
2. `atom.gyp` includes `sources.gypi`.
3. `atom.gyp` has a new target, `generated_sources`, which contains all the `.coffee`/`.cson` files, and uses two rules to tell gyp how to compile them. The rules invoke the new `script/compile-coffee` and `script/compile-cson` files once for each file.
4. gyp generates one `Makefile` for each rule to actually perform the compilation.
5. `script/copy-files-to-bundle` now takes the `compiled_sources_dir` variable as an argument, and copies files both from there and from the repository into the `Resources` directory.

By putting the compilation into a different target, we can do it in parallel with compiling/linking our binaries. And gyp automatically runs `make` using `-j$(sysctl -n hw.ncpu)`, so compilation of `.coffee`/`.cson` files happens in parallel, too.

These changes reduce clean build time on my MacBook Pro from 55 seconds to 31 seconds.

data.title: SyntaxError on startup
data.body:
I encountered this error after built on a fresh new Mac machine (sorry for pasting image instead of pasting text, because I was accessing the machine via VNC and didn't have a meta key on my keyboard):
![Screenshot of Xcloud at 2013-03-04 15:20:27](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/639601/215631/6ddd641e-849c-11e2-953d-69b19e4f9e19.png)

This exception was triggered when parsing the `Atom.app/Contents/Resources/src/app/keymaps/apple.json`, and the content of `apple.json` is blank.

I doubt something wrong happened when compiling the `cson` files, but there was no error given when doing `rake install`.

data.title: Ruby auto-indent prevents inserting spaces before certain closing tokens
data.body:
Enter the following code into a Ruby file in Atom:

``` ruby
  myhash = { :foo => 'bar'
  }
```

Now try to insert a space before the closing brace. CAN'T DO IT. I'd expect to still be able to push that sucker over if the inclination strikes me. Works the same for `end` in a method declaration.

data.title: Drag and drop images onto Atom actually works
data.body: I accidentally dropped some images onto my Atom editor on the way to the trash can.  Atom dutifully replaced the window contents with the image.  I had to restart Atom to get the editor back.

data.body: Not really sure if this qualifies as a bug or not. I use [Divvy](http://mizage.com/divvy/) for window management. When I use it with atom, the window resizes, but the internal UI stays as it was prior to being resized.

data.title: Fuzzy file finder not too fuzzy
data.body:
If you open up github/github in Sublime Text 2, press `cmd-t` to open up the fuzzy file finder and type in `show view` you get this:

![Screen Shot 2013-02-28 at 4 15 24 PM](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/244/207932/4026d404-8205-11e2-8a8d-1a0de93aaab6.png)

which is basically what I expect. If you do the same in Atom, you get this:

![Screen Shot 2013-02-28 at 4 16 52 PM](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/244/207934/6c15d31c-8205-11e2-8803-c15bceb66582.png)

It looks like Atom is only performing exact matches here.

data.title: Opening atom via symlink causes "Modified" status bar to not display
data.body:
This guy doesn't show up in the status bar when for modified files when you open atom via a symlink:

![image](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/2/207717/24e833c8-81fa-11e2-9214-63741467f7f8.png)

Fails:

``` sh
ln -s ~/github/github ~/Code/github
atom ~/Code/github
```

Works:

```
atom ~/github/github
```

@kevinsawicki

data.title: Explain what `meta` means in the docs.
data.body:
It might be obvious, but there is no place in the documentation where it explains what `meta` is. On the other hand, the second paragraph starts like this:

> If there's one key-command you learn in Atom, it should be meta-p.

So, I read that, I open Atom and my first thought is, where is `meta`? I'm a vim user, so for me it would be `,` or `Ctrl`, but I'm on mac, so following the OS conventions I could thought that `meta` is `Cmd`. But, does Atom follow the OS conventions? So, where is `meta` if I use it on Linux instead?

All in all, I have to think really hard to figure out where the most important key is, even before starting to use the editor.

data.title: No way to get tree view back using command palette unless you have file open
data.body:
I closed all files and accidentally hit esc in the tree view. At this point, atom was a gaping dark void. The command palette looked like this:

![Screen Shot 2013-02-28 at 3 47 00 PM](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/235/207186/0986ab12-81e8-11e2-94b2-3b7a64d3c156.png)

I couldn't remember the keymap to toggle it. Luckily I opened a file and then I could get to the tree view toggle from the command palette.

Having a few other options in the command palette based on a really blank slate would be super useful.

data.title: Move all code and resources into Atom.framework
data.body:
All our native code now gets built into `Atom.framework`. `Atom.app` and `Atom Helper.app` both link against this framework. All resources other than a couple of main-bundle-only ones (e.g., `atom.icns`) go into `Atom.framework`.

Note that this means that there's no compile- or link-time separation between main process code and helper process code. We could introduce a compile-time separation by building main process and helper process code into separate static libraries with mutually exclusive include paths, if we want.

Atom.framework exports a single symbol: `AtomMain()`. `Atom.app` and `Atom Helper.app` contain a single source file: `main.cpp`. `main()` just calls `AtomMain()`.

All frameworks are placed in `Atom.app/Contents/Frameworks`. We now link against all frameworks using `@rpath`-based install names, which allows `Atom.app` and `Atom Helper.app` to find them automatically based on their own `LD_RUNPATH_SEARCH_PATH` settings. We use `install_name_tool` at build time on each of our three binaries (`Atom.app`, `Atom Helper.app`, `Atom.framework`) to set the install names.

By reducing duplication of code and resources between `Atom.app` and `Atom Helper.app` (and the `EH`/`NP` copies of `Atom Helper.app`), this reduces the size of the total `Atom.app` bundle from 145MB to 82MB. By compiling `.coffee` and `.cson` files only once, clean build time drops from 114 seconds to 79 seconds on my MacBook Pro.

data.title: Many tests fail when Atom is built/run under a symlink
data.body:
The new Mac Janky server builds everything under `/var/lib/jenkins`. On Mac's, `/var` is a symlink to `/private/var`. This leads to [many test failures](https://janky.rs.github.com/298269/output), such as:

